qas.question: Why were alternative energy sources judged uneconomical in 2001?

answers.text: low (less than 50¢/gal) fuel prices, long distances and low population

qas.question: How much does gas cost in Alaska, in comparison to the national average?
What are some reasons why gas prices may vary in Alaska, especially?

answers.text: transportation costs, seasonal usage peaks, nearby petroleum development infrastructure

qas.question: What does Alaska's economy heavily rely on?
What purpose does diesel fuel have in Alaska?

answers.text: heating, transportation, electric power and light

plausible_answers.text: low (less than 50¢/gal) fuel prices, long distances and low population

plausible_answers.text: low (less than 50¢/gal) fuel prices, long distances and low population

plausible_answers.text: transportation costs, seasonal usage peaks, nearby petroleum development infrastructure

qas.question: What are some reasons why gas prices may be stable in Alaska, especially?
What does Alaska's economy not rely on?

context: Alaska's economy depends heavily on increasingly expensive <a3_0><b9_0>diesel fuel<b9_0/><a3_0/> for <a4_0>heating, transportation, electric power and light<a4_0/>. Though wind and hydroelectric power are abundant and underdeveloped, proposals for statewide energy systems (e.g. with special low-cost electric interties) were judged uneconomical (at the time of the report, 2001) due to <a0_0><b5_0><b6_0>low (less than 50¢/gal) fuel prices, long distances and low population<b6_0/><b5_0/><a0_0/>. The cost of a gallon of gas in urban Alaska today is usually <a1_0><b7_0>30–60¢ higher<b7_0/><a1_0/> than the national average; prices in rural areas are generally significantly higher but vary widely depending on <a2_0><b8_0>transportation costs, seasonal usage peaks, nearby petroleum development infrastructure<b8_0/><a2_0/> and many other factors.
